entry.title: Visualizing pnr changes over time using flot.js
entry.summary:
Around 2 weeks back, pnr prediction tool got heavy criticism from a user. He argued that there was no prediction algorithm being used and the result was just a random prediction. We tried to explain how our algorithm worked and how we use curve fitting to arrive at a reasonably accurate prediction. We also showed him the accuracy of our pnr prediction and argued that we cannot achieve such a high accuracy by writing any random function. But it was tough to convince him and to his credit, we were not showing any data that we used for prediction in the website.

A decision was made to show the user the data we use for prediction. This will help users take an informed decision rather than blindly trusting pnr.me. If the user is adventurous enough he can arrive at his own prediction using the data

Data

The data we want to share with the user is the exact data that we use for prediction. From our database, we select 15 pnr numbers which match the characteristics of the pnr being queried. Each of these pnrs will have information about how the waiting list changed over time and our prediction tool uses this data to arrive at a prediction.

Visualization

The pnr change data for a pnr is a set of points where x co-ordinate represents the number of hours before departure and y co-ordinate represents the waiting list number. We decided to plot all the 15 curves in a graph

Technologies used

Our initial idea was to use D3.js as it is a very powerful tool to visualize data. But we were already using JQuery and it made much more sense to use a plugin for JQuery than another complete JS library. Enter flot.js.

Using flot was very simple and here is the sample code we used

<head>
<script src="http://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/jquery/2.0.3/jquery.min.js" charset="utf-8"></script>
<script src="http://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/flot/0.8.1/jquery.flot.min.js" charset="utf-8"></script>
</head>
<body>
<div id="graph" class="graph" style="width:1000px;height:1000px"></div>
<script type="text/javascript">
var data_4 = {"lines": [{"points": [[407.0, 33.0], [431.0, 34.0], [455.0, 37.0], [479.0, 37.0], [503.0, 38.0], [527.0, 40.0], [551.0, 41.0], [574.0, 41.0], [582.0, 43.0]]}, {"points": [[23.0, 9.0], [47.0, 12.0], [71.0, 12.0], [71.0, 12.0], [95.0, 12.0], [119.0, 16.0], [143.0, 16.0], [148.0, 16.0]]}, {"points": [[23.0, 0.0], [47.0, 23.0], [71.0, 47.0], [95.0, 56.0], [119.0, 73.0], [143.0, 89.0], [167.0, 104.0], [191.0, 111.0]]}, {"points": [[119.0, 0.0], [143.0, 2.0], [167.0, 13.0], [177.0, 16.0]]}, {"points": [[0.0, 269.0], [3.0, 291.0], [23.0, 349.0], [47.0, 383.0], [71.0, 399.0], [95.0, 411.0], [119.0, 434.0], [140.0, 440.0], [140.0, 440.0], [160.0, 447.0]]}, {"points": [[95.0, 0.0], [119.0, 2.0], [143.0, 4.0], [162.0, 5.0], [191.0, 7.0], [215.0, 8.0], [239.0, 9.0], [262.0, 11.0], [287.0, 14.0], [311.0, 16.0], [335.0, 16.0], [359.0, 16.0], [381.0, 16.0], [407.0, 17.0], [431.0, 19.0], [455.0, 19.0], [479.0, 22.0], [503.0, 25.0], [527.0, 25.0], [538.0, 25.0]]}, {"points": [[47.0, 0.0], [71.0, 2.0], [95.0, 5.0], [119.0, 16.0], [143.0, 28.0], [154.0, 31.0]]}, {"points": [[23.0, 97.0], [47.0, 122.0], [71.0, 134.0], [77.0, 139.0]]}, {"points": [[47.0, 0.0], [71.0, 10.0], [95.0, 11.0], [119.0, 18.0], [132.0, 22.0], [132.0, 22.0]]}, {"points": [[0.0, 19.0], [3.0, 56.0], [23.0, 87.0], [47.0, 102.0], [71.0, 115.0], [95.0, 121.0], [119.0, 132.0], [143.0, 136.0], [153.0, 141.0]]}, {"points": [[0.0, 37.0], [3.0, 37.0], [21.0, 56.0], [47.0, 78.0], [71.0, 94.0], [95.0, 101.0], [119.0, 104.0], [143.0, 111.0], [167.0, 116.0], [191.0, 118.0], [215.0, 119.0], [239.0, 119.0], [261.0, 119.0], [277.0, 119.0], [308.0, 126.0], [335.0, 132.0], [359.0, 132.0], [383.0, 132.0], [407.0, 133.0], [431.0, 133.0], [455.0, 133.0], [479.0, 133.0], [503.0, 134.0], [527.0, 136.0], [551.0, 136.0], [575.0, 136.0], [599.0, 136.0], [623.0, 136.0], [646.0, 136.0]]}, {"points": [[71.0, 0.0], [95.0, 5.0], [119.0, 11.0], [143.0, 19.0], [167.0, 49.0], [191.0, 50.0], [204.0, 53.0]]}, {"points": [[71.0, 0.0], [93.0, 10.0], [115.0, 17.0]]}, {"points": [[3.0, 0.0], [23.0, 4.0], [47.0, 23.0], [71.0, 30.0], [95.0, 38.0], [119.0, 43.0], [143.0, 51.0], [165.0, 63.0]]}, {"points": [[0.0, 7.0], [21.0, 11.0], [44.0, 14.0], [69.0, 14.0], [82.0, 14.0]]}]}
var options = {
    series: {
        lines: { show: true },
        points: { show: true }
    },
    grid:{hoverable: true, clickable:true}
};
if ("lines" in data_4){
    $(function () {
        var plot_array = []
        for (var i = 0; i < data_4["lines"].length; i++){
            if ("points" in data_4["lines"][i]){
                plot_array.push({
                    data : data_4["lines"][i]["points"],
                })
            }
        }
        $.plot($("#graph"), plot_array, options);
    });
}
</script>
</body>

Changelist

  • Introduced visualization of data used for prediction in To book or not and pnr prediction
  • Introduced a slightly better algorithm for prediction
  • To book or not page has detailed form fields

Update

We greatly appeciate Anand Chitipothu`s suggestions and have gone ahead and implemented them. a short list of features implemented

  • y-axis on the right side
  • x-axis shows number of days than number of hours
  • y-axis has labels which clearly specify waiting list
  • on hovering on any of the points, their corresponding x and y are displayed

We have also decided to open source our prediction engine and you can expect the announcement in next few weeks

entry.title: How we solved the immense pain of error code 500:internal service error
entry.summary:
We explained earlier how our servers went down crashing, after being shared by mr rodinhood. We needed a fix and we needed it fast

What the problem was not

One of our first assumption was that the error had something to do with Apache. Reading a lot of hackernews makes you believe that Apache is the culprit behind any server side error and nginx is the solution. But as we deep dived into the problem some things became very clear

  • Our Apache server was never throttled
  • What went down was the application itself, to be more clear the prediction engine of pnr.me

skeleton of pnr.me

pnr.me has two main components, a flask powered web app and a python predictor daemon communicating with each other using zmq. There is good reason why we arrived at this design. Predictor daemon is a number crunching application which required good amount of memory. To make matters worse, it was using scipy which is a memory heavy python library. Hence it was not advisable to have the predictor application embedded in the web app as mod_wsgi will have a tough time serving this memory heavy app.

Now call it bad code, our predictor daemon was throwing some exception and dying at regular intervals. To make the matter worse, we had not set up any kind of monitoring mechanism which would inform us when the predictor daemon goes down. As a ugly hack, we stumbled upon this beautiful code which would re spawn a daemon if it gets killed or if it is stopped by some random reason

until (python predictor_daemon.py); do
    echo "Server 'myserver' crashed with exit code $?.  Respawning.." >&2
    sleep 1
done

Internal service errors would still show for users but at least it wouldn`t affect others from accessing the website

The web app

Once internal server error of predictor daemon got almost resolved, we were quite sure that we would not get any more internal service errors. As the great Thorin Oakenshield once said "I've never been so wrong in all my life".

We deploy pnr.me after doing basic testing. But these basic tests cannot handle blackswan errors like the one i recently faced. I was getting pymongo.errors.OperationFailure: quota exceeded error and because of this, the webapp was throwing an internal service error. How did pnr.me solve pymongo.errors.OperationFailure: quota exceeded when using MongoLab is a story for another blog post.

We cannot solve all Blackswan events however hard we try. We needed an alert mechanism by which we could react fast to these errors. By following the beautiful articles on how to set up a SMTPHandler for flask and how to use GMail SMTP server with logging module, we created a alert mechanism which would mail us the second any error is thrown by the flask web server

Final setup and improvement

  • We will be alerted by email when some error is thrown by flask.
  • Our predictor daemon will re spawn within a second of dying. We can fix the error later as all the errors are anyways logged
  • A big TODO is to create such alerts for python jobs which run independent of the flask web service

entry.title: How we got our first thousand visitors
entry.summary:
pnr.me was built and it was working like a breeze, but sadly there were no visitors. What is the use of building an awesome website and no one to benefit from it?. Decision was made that we would publicize pnr.me in the following 4 sites

  • hackernews
  • hackerstreet
  • reddit
  • rodinhood

We had a mix of successes and failures and here is how it all went

Hackernews

Hackernews need no introduction and we assumed that although the audience is highly US centric, there will be sizable amount of Indian audience who would be interested in pnr prediction. That assumption turned out to be entirely wrong and we got no up votes for the original post.

Hacker Street India

hackerstreet is a community of Indian entrepreneurs and technical enthusiasts with heavy influences from hackernews. Pnr prediction is a problem most of them have faced at least once and we got amazing response both in terms of visits and feedback from Hackerstreet

Reddit

We were very confused about which sub reddit to use. Should we go for India sub reddit or trains sub reddit?. We finally decided to publicize in trains sub reddit, assuming that since our product had everything to do with trains, it should be the right place to publicize. We were wrong and we got more down votes than up votes

The Rodinhoods

We stumbled on a rodinhoods post about possibility of using past data to predict pnr charting status while browsing for pnr prediction. We found the community to be active and were giving generally good feedback and hence we created a showcase post in rodinhoods.

The initial response were good and our traffic data was showing a spike. But we were not prepared for traffic that would come after Alok Rodinhood Kejriwal shared the post in his facebook page. we had a huge jump in traffic which caused an internal service error and we were offline for almost two hours. Unexpected but an amazing marketing win

October 29 and 30th spike is due to hackerstreet and November 6th spike is due to rodinhoods

Lessons Learned

  • Always publicize it to the right audience. Do not rely on a minority audience as the chances that they will be able to up vote or discuss about your work is highly remote
  • Do not post on sub reddits with very few audience
  • Keep a close watch on errors. First impression could very well be the last one.

entry.title: Why we created pnr.me and how does it work?
entry.summary:
pnr.me was created to ease the difficulty passengers were having in predicting whether or not their waiting list train tickets will get confirmed. Here is a brief introduction to the problem and how we are trying to solve this problem

The problem

Indian railways is the biggest mover of people and goods in India. The demand far exceeds supply and it is very usual for busy trains to have a waiting list of more than 500. The holders of these waiting list tickets do not have a right to board the train and will only get that privilege if some one with a confirmed ticket cancels his/her ticket.

How would you know whether your waiting list will get confirmed or not?. Simple answer is no, you cannot. But by looking at past data, one can predict with reasonable accuracy whether waiting list ticket will get confirmed or not.

The solution

pnr prediction tool takes pnr number as input and tries to predict the ticket`s final charting status. The prediction tool works by looking at similar pnr numbers and how their waiting list changed over time. It uses this data to make a sufficiently accurate prediction

Some stats

Every year indian railways generate around 750 crores as cancellation charges. Every 1 in 3 train tickets booked are cancelled. pnr.me hopes to reduce that number.
